title: Jupyter Notebook Example
text:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

mtcars = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/plotly/datasets/master/mtcars.csv")


plt.scatter(x=mtcars.wt, y=mtcars.mpg)
plt.title("Miles per Gallon vs Weight")
plt.show()








The heavier the vehicle, the worse the gas mileage!

title: Quarto Documents
text:
Quarto allows us to add computations from a variety of languages to our markdown-like documents.
Below is an R code block followed by its output:

library(ggplot2)

mtcars |>
    ggplot(aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
    geom_point() +
    labs(title = "Miles per Gallon vs Weight")








Below is a Python code block followed by its output:

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

mtcars = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/plotly/datasets/master/mtcars.csv")

plt.scatter(x=mtcars.wt, y=mtcars.mpg)
plt.title("Miles per Gallon vs Weight")
plt.show()








To see a page created from a native Jupyter Notebook, see here!

title: Data Science Weekly Drills
text: Data newcomers, hobbyists, and professionals are encouraged to create and share a data visualization, model, app, or other data-related output based on a weekly topic or shared dataset posted in [Discord channel], on [bletchley.org], and [social media]. Our goal is to foster our community to share tips, tricks, assistance, and inspiration for creating data output.

title: Examples
text:
Assume the popular “mtcars” dataset was shared for the weekly data science drill. Below are some ways you could visualize and share your work so others can see how you did it.










Quarto Documents





This page was created from a .qmd file!

title: Examples
text: Data newcomers, hobbyists, and professionals are encouraged to create and share a data visualization, model, app, or other data-related output based on a weekly topic or shared dataset posted in [Discord channel], on [bletchley.org], and [social media]. Our goal is to foster our community to share tips, tricks, assistance, and inspiration for creating data output.

title: Examples
text:
Each week a topic or dataset will be shared [Discord channel], on [bletchley.org], and [social media]

Find a dataset related to the topic of the week
If a dataset is provided, download it

Explore the data and create a visualization, model, app, or other data-related output, using the tool of your choice
Share your creation

The goal is to practice and improve, so even a simple graph that shows something interesting or leverages a new package is worth sharing!
Paste a screenshot of your creation to [Discord channel] using the hashtags [insert hashtags]
We also encourage you to share how you created it and link to any related code, notebook, or live output so others can learn and find inspiration from you. See below for a few examples.

Prizes, badges, social media shoutouts for:

Best data visualization
Most interesting insight
Most innovative creation

title: Examples
text:
Assume the popular “mtcars” dataset was shared for the weekly data science drill. Below are some ways you could visualize and share your work so others can see how you did it.


Render on GitHub



Render as webpage via GitHub Pages. See documentation for other ways to publish.



If JavaScript is your thing, try Observable notebooks

plt.scatter(x=mtcars.wt, y=mtcars.mpg)
plt.title("Miles per Gallon vs Weight")
plt.show()








The heavier the vehicle, the worse the gas mileage!
